positive.review:
The core of the gameâ€”the fishing itselfâ€”feels very polished and satisfying. Casting your line and using various retrieval techniques like "Twitching" or "Stop & Go" to trigger a bite feels great.
The game goes into great detail regarding your equipment. You assemble your own individual setup consisting of rod, reel, line, and bait. Attributes such as reel drag (max drag), line strength/test, stretch, and lure size are crucial for success. A big plus is the ability to carry and use multiple rods simultaneously, increasing your chances of a catch. The time of day also plays a major role, as fish are active at different times.

The game requires economic thinking. Traveling to different locations can be quite expensive, meaning if you go unprepared, you will lose money. You are forced to fish profitably to ensure the trip yields a return on investment.
This creates a strong motivation to tweak your setups to improve bite rates and profit margins. Whether you build a "universal setup" or specialize in specific fish is up to youâ€”as long as the cash flow is positive at the end of the day.

There is practically no manual or tutorial explaining exactly how mechanics work. The motto is strictly "Trial and Error." While the shop descriptions for products are immersiveâ€”written almost like real-life advertisements that hint at their functionâ€”the game can be unnecessarily confusing. For example, some fish have cryptic preferences for baits like "narrow spoons" or "nano spoons," but the shop doesn't use these names (listing only "casting" or "slop spoons" instead). This is very confusing for new players.
Additionally, you get bottlenecked by your gear. Essential items, like stronger fishing lines, are unlocked quite late, which artificially slows down progress.

Progression is a double-edged sword. Without "Premium" status, leveling takes a long time. If you want to progress faster and get more XP and money, you have to pay (approx. â‚¬10/month). While you do receive a small amount of premium currency at the start to buy some advantageous gear, the shop itself is a bit of a mess. Premium goods and tournament rewards are mixed in with regular items, and there is no option to hide them, making the shop cluttered.

The game offers a fantastic fishing feel and motivates players through the search for the perfect setup. However, high travel costs and a lack of explanations make the entry difficult. It is a game for patient players who are willing to learn through failure and donâ€™t mind a certain amount of grind (or reaching for their wallet).

Since the Maldives Update, weâ€™ve been getting feedback about the toughest battles in the game - the epic fights with Unique Swordfish and Black Marlin. Some of you mentioned these fights felt a bit too long, or that fish were escaping too often due to low line tension.


While that behavior isnâ€™t a bug, as when these powerful fish try to escape, they can sometimes swim quickly toward you causing the line to go slack, we still wanted to make things more enjoyable for our players. Over the past few weeks, weâ€™ve been analyzing your feedback and in-game data to find the best balance between realistic challenge and fun gameplay.

Introduction: Why did I start? And why am I still playing?
I started Fishing Planet almost by accident â€” I was looking for something calm to take my mind off shooters and RPGs. I thought, "Fishing? Easy. Calmly. Naturally." Oh, how wrong I was.

It's not just fishing. This is a simulator where every detail â€” from the wind to the depth, from the type of bait to the behavior of the fish â€” matters. And if you want to catch a trophy perch or a giant catfish, get ready for it to be a battle, not a walk.

Gameplay: Realism on the verge of fanaticism
1. The physics and behavior of fish are your main opponent
The fish here is not just a model that bites on a timer. She's thinking. She has:

Behavioral patterns: Some fish are active in the morning, others in the evening. Some like shade, others like open water.
Reaction to the bait: if you pull too hard, she may get scared and leave. If it's too slow, it ignores you.
Resistance: that's where the fun begins. Each fish pulls in its own way. Pike â€” sharp, short bursts. Catfish is a powerful, exhausting drawling fight. And the salmon? He just wants to escape into the ocean. And you're going to have to stop him.
, Advice for a beginner: Take your time! Even if the fish bites, do not immediately raise the rod. Let her "play", let her swallow. Otherwise, it's a cliff. 

2. Gear: Set up like in a combat simulator
Here you can choose:

Fishing rods (spinning, fly fishing, float, bottom) â€” each for its own style.
Coils â€” with different gear ratios, brakes, and weights.
Fishing lines â€” monofilament, braided, fluorocarbon â€” each type affects sensitivity and strength.
Baits are wobblers, spinners, silicone, live bait... and each one works under certain conditions.
Subtlety: For example, it is better to use slow baits in cold water. They're fast in the heat. And if the water is cloudy, bright colors. And yes, depending on the depth, you need to change the weight of the bait. Have you forgotten? The fish won't bite. 

3. Environment: Not just a background, it's part of the game
Fishing Planet maps are not just beautiful pictures. They're alive:

The wind affects the wave â†’ changes the casting trajectory.
Water temperature â€” fish behaves differently.
Time of day â€” morning/evening = peak activity.
The weather â€” rain, clouds, sun â€” affects everything.
Underwater terrain â€” rocks, driftwood, grass â€” fish hide where you don't expect them.
Life Hack: Use the echo sounder! It will show you where the fish is, at what depth and what size. Without him, you're a blind fisherman. 

Game modes: From singles to tournaments
, Free fishing
Ideal for beginners and those who just want to relax. You choose a location, gear, and go ahead. But even here you can spend hours catching one fish, because it doesn't want to bite. That's life.

, Tournaments
Everything is serious here. You're being evaluated by:

The size of the fish
The number of people caught
Fishing time
Tournaments are held in real time, which means you need to be online at the right time. And yes, the competitors are real fans. It happens that you lose because you didn't notice a change in the weather.

, Survival Mode
The toughest one. You fish to get money for gear, food, and boat repairs. If you don't catch them, you'll starve to death. Yes, in a fishing game. ðŸ˜…

ðŸ–¥ï¸ Graphics and sound: Dive to 200%
The graphics are one of the best in the genre. The water looks real, reflections, waves, splashes â€” everything is at the highest level. Especially on a good PC.

Sound is a different story. The sound of waves, chirping birds, squishing fish in the water â€” creates an atmosphere as if you are really on the shore of the lake.

Minus: The game may slow down on weak PCs. Especially on large maps with lots of objects. 

Monetization: Free, but with a catch
The game is free, but there is an in-game store.:

Premium class gear â€” for real money.
Locations â€” some are only available for a fee.
The skins for fishing rods and boats are purely decorative.
But! You can play it completely for free. You'll just have to wait a little while until you save up money for the best gear. Or... Become a fishing master and win tournaments.

In my opinion, Monetization is not intrusive. It doesn't hurt if you're not a fan of shopping. But if you want to get the best reel quickly, pay up. 

, Community and multiplayer
You can catch with friends or random players. Sometimes it's fun when everyone is trying to catch one big fish. Sometimes it's stressful when someone steals your "hot" spot.

There are forums and Discord servers where tactics, gear, and locations are discussed. A very active community.

, Pros and cons
, Advantages:
Incredible realism
Deep mechanics of gear and fish behavior
Beautiful graphics and sound
Different modes â€” from relaxation to extreme survival
Free foundation
, Cons:
Learning curve â€” it will be difficult for beginners
Sometimes bugs (for example, fish freezes or doesn't bite for no reason)
Monetization can be annoying if you want everything at once.
Some locations require purchase
Bottom line: Who is this game for?
âœ… For you if:

Do you like deep mechanics simulators?
Do you like realism and detail?
Are you ready to learn and experiment
Do you want to relax, but still receive a challenge?
 Not for you if:

Do you want fast, simple fishing without strategy
Do not tolerate when the game "does not work" â€” you need to work
Not ready to waste time studying gear and conditions
Final verdict: 9/10
Fishing Planet is not just a game. It's an experience. This is that rare simulator that makes you feel like a real fisherman â€” with joy from the first catch and despair from the tenth cliff. There is no "easy" here. There is â€” "interesting". And that's what makes it unique.

Last word: If you haven't caught at least one fish in 5 hours, don't give up. Just change the bait. Or the time of day. Or the weather. Or... start over. After all, fishing is about patience. And about winning over yourself. 

P.S. Yes, I'm still trying to catch that 120-centimeter pike in the "Big Lake". If you have any advice, write to us. I'm desperate. ðŸ˜…

I reaaaally wanted to play a decent fishing game and I can't find one honestly. This game has the best fishing simulation while you're on the edge of a lake and that part was fun, as fun as fishing is. But the rest of the game isnt fun at all, I wouldnt even consider the rest of it a game, its more like a fishing simulator inside of an ad. I put 10 bucks into it to experience what the game was but they still peppered me with in game ads even as a premium subscriber or whatever. Even everything physical outside of the 80% of the game thats made up of UI and ads is pretty bad, character customization is basically, you can be a different race. You're character walks around like a dummy on a stick with a wheel at its base, and you walk in very confined spaces, dictated by invisible walls. There's more but I'll just say the game lacks logic in a lot of areas and it leaves people confused.
Ngl its preatty boring after 30 min of game play. I just wasted my time on a mid fishing game that is simple as heck in the start and then turns into astrophysics.

Game is pretty fun but there are a few galring QoL issues that don't make sense coming from a game expecting $$$ micro-transactions.

1. Character takes unecessary amount of time switiching rods as automatic actions are performed after each cast. Would prefer to have the choice to manually reset the rod after each cast so multi-rod fishing seems more feasible. It was nice to see that the different rod stands had an effect on switching speed but having the character stand in front of you, motionless while he/she flicks some lever on the rod, all the while a fish on another line escapes is pure rage bait from the devs.

2. Really hostile pricing models. The ideal tackle or line, lure etc. etc. that you might want for the fish you're going for will be gate kept via the in game currency. forcing you into a suboptimal set up purely because you dont want to spend real money on the game.

3. The amount of false positives with fish being lost to line tension is ridiculous. Tension could be maintained perfectly and the fish will somehow fall off as its being pulled from the water into your hand. If you want to keep that mechanic in the game then at least give us the option of a net or something to help pull the fish in. Level 30 currently and no such option available.

4. The amount of times ive lost multiple fish because the game won't let me switch rods on a holder is becoming an issue to the point I have to change my review and not recommend this game unless you have prior experience in similar games. Its a level of cruelty that shouldnt be an issue, if the devs simply played their game. And certainly one would expect issues like this to be non existent after being out for 10 years. Truly a terrible experience. Please do something about it as it is limiting this game severely

If you don't care about optimisation and just want to throw a line in the water to get some fish then its a pretty good game. The more you try to optimise, the more the game breaks ://

Uses Denuvo

Edit; The Developer decided to respond on why they use Denuvo. Below are just a few reason to be wary of developers who use Denuvo.

Denuvo performs constant integrity checks, encryption/decryption, and verification of the game executable during runtime, which can consume CPU resources.

Independent testing showed frame-time spikes and longer load times when Denuvo was enabled.

Some versions of Denuvo require periodic, or constant, online authentication. This can lock out legitimate users when Denuvoâ€™s servers are down or when internet access is unreliable.

Because Denuvo performs repeated reads (and possibly writes), this can contribute to increased wear on SSDs.

Because Denuvo is proprietary, users donâ€™t really know exactly what checks are happening, how often, or how invasive they are.

If Fishing Planet removes Denuvo in the future, I'll gladly update my review, but as it stands, I can't recommend it.

It's an addicting game and really good but far too many micro transactions.

The game is heavily dependent on bait coins.  You aren't "required" to purchase anything but you will be stuck in Texas catching 0.3 pound bluegill if you don't.  Pond passes, advanced license's and in game credits won't carry you to any fun.  If you buy a $39 dollar pack, you'll be fishing in the Congo with the biggest fish and best rods immediately.    

The leaderboards are also quite laughable, there are no 1 million pound fish. 

Removal of baitcoin and actual substantial rewards for fish you catch would be better for the game but not so great for the devs pockets.  I'm not against a few packs, but baitcoin is clear pay to win.

Am I still playing?  Sure, but not if another game close to this with no baitcoin comes out....

Listen, I downloaded Fishing Planet because I thought itâ€™d be a relaxing fishing game. You knowâ€”cast a line, vibe with some southern tunes, catch a pixelated fish or two, and feel like a serene outdoorsy legend.

WRONG.

This game decided it wanted to be a hyperrealistic fishing simulator. I spent 47 real-life minutes staring at digital water while my avatar slowly froze to death in photorealistic rain.

I finally hooked one, and the game made me reel for eight full minutes while adjusting my line tension like I was defusing a bomb. I think my thumb developed emotional trauma. By the time I caught it, I felt like Iâ€™d actually gone fishingâ€”minus the tan and plus a mild existential crisis.

And the realism! My bait ran out. My rod broke. I had to file taxes on my in-game fishing income. I didnâ€™t sign up for Fishing Bureaucracy Simulator 3000.

Sure, the graphics are stunning, the water physics are gorgeous, and the fish AI deserves an Oscarâ€”but please, I play games to escape reality, not to be humbled by a trout.

I really enjoy the game, believe me its a great time if you are into fishing sims. However you will hit an absolute pay wall around lvl40-50 as the game just makes it nearly impossible to get levels. I do encourage people purchase content when you find a genuine love for the game, but the nickle and diming people on each individual map is just egregious and downright greedy. I can't reccomend this game to players unless you are okay with purchase majority of the content. The overwhelming majority of players will not be able to hit that 800-1k hours to go from lvl40-94 (asuming you have good spawn data and target uniques). The amount of money they want you to spend to get full access is around 150-200USD. Most players who come to this game end up quitting around lvl50 because the grind of being stuck in Weeping Willow and Blue Crab Island is so bad.

They want to break you down and have you purchase content. At its core this game is designed to fleece money from you.

                                                                                   *BUYER BEWARE*
What a piece of crap game!  You really need to make a game actually WORTH playing... Freaking unplayable beyond belief!
I don't fish but people who fish probs good game, very pay to fish. at the prices they have you could go out and fish for real.

Unfortunately, everything about this game is geared to push you to buy DLC.
 
This wouldn't be a challenge if, in the course of this goal, they didn't make the "free" part of the game a waiting simulator that destroys the will to want to play anymore. The free-grind in this game makes World of Tanks look like a Sprint to the Finish. 

If you expect to play this game 100% free: Don't bother. 

I found the purchase options ambiguous and vague.... as if the game devs are uninterested in helping you determine what equipment will help you further the game.... (causing a feedback loop of Purchase, realise it's the wrong purchase, grind free, purchase, realise.... etc)

I can't recommend it. 

Stick a price tag on it and add some decent content to begin with. This game has no value as a Free-To-Play

Balanced to be grindy and make you pay. Not balanced to try to make a fun game.


Edit for developer response:

"The game is free-to-play"
-Being free-to-play might be a valid defense if the game wasn't intentionally made pay-to-win. Being free doesn't absolve the game of any criticisms.


"if you prefer simply fishing and enjoying the experience rather than leveling up quickly, you donâ€™t need to buy any DLCs"
-When the game tells me, after every single trip, that my fish would be worth more if I paid real money, 'simply fishing' is not preferred. When the XP and economy is intentionally balanced to be painstakingly slow, the experience is not enjoyable. Also, replying to tell me I don't need to buy any DLCs for a product designed to sell DLCs, with in-game pop-up ads for those DLCs, is pretty laughable.


"As you progress, youâ€™ll unlock new waterways and gain access to more powerful gear in the in-game shop"
-It takes hundreds of hours and thousands of caught fish just to unlock the ability to fish in the ocean... in a fishing game... where the main menu is an ocean scene. Obviously that doesn't sound reasonable but it's not intended to be.


"There are also plenty of activities to explore, including missions, challenges, competitions, and events. I hope you find the time to give it another try and enjoy more of what the game offers."
-The experience is too much of a chore to care.

What kind of potato you guys are using as your game's server?
Game play can't even last 3 minutes without breaking connection.
It's unplayable now.

If your designing a fishing game and decide to include lines getting snagged and you suggest a solution and the solution is the equivalent of chucking the fishing rod into the lake than im not playing anymore. Update the tutorial or fix the bug that disappears the entire fishing rod upon cutting the line. Do no recommend, graphics and pop up ads are way too high for this level of BS
its alright, very boring while playing alone, takes wayyy to long to get to level 100, P2W game

this game is for hardcore fishing simulator enjoyers, not for casuals with the occasional fishing itch, because it did not scratch my itch. It's too complicated, and not every cast is a guaranteed catch. It's also a money-monger, and forces you to spend for fishing licenses. Instructions and other aspects of the game is not easily taught (i still don't know how to cast further than 10m). This game has left me unsatisfied and disappointed.
I HATE THIS GAME, i accidently bought items that didint work with the other items i had causing me to get softlocked but this game has no fix for that such as softlock prevention or progress reseting
Ngl its preatty boring after 30 min of game play. I just wasted my time on a mid fishing game that is simple as heck in the start and then turns into astrophysics.

I reaaaally wanted to play a decent fishing game and I can't find one honestly. This game has the best fishing simulation while you're on the edge of a lake and that part was fun, as fun as fishing is. But the rest of the game isnt fun at all, I wouldnt even consider the rest of it a game, its more like a fishing simulator inside of an ad. I put 10 bucks into it to experience what the game was but they still peppered me with in game ads even as a premium subscriber or whatever. Even everything physical outside of the 80% of the game thats made up of UI and ads is pretty bad, character customization is basically, you can be a different race. You're character walks around like a dummy on a stick with a wheel at its base, and you walk in very confined spaces, dictated by invisible walls. There's more but I'll just say the game lacks logic in a lot of areas and it leaves people confused.

Game is pretty fun but there are a few galring QoL issues that don't make sense coming from a game expecting $$$ micro-transactions.

1. Character takes unecessary amount of time switiching rods as automatic actions are performed after each cast. Would prefer to have the choice to manually reset the rod after each cast so multi-rod fishing seems more feasible. It was nice to see that the different rod stands had an effect on switching speed but having the character stand in front of you, motionless while he/she flicks some lever on the rod, all the while a fish on another line escapes is pure rage bait from the devs.

2. Really hostile pricing models. The ideal tackle or line, lure etc. etc. that you might want for the fish you're going for will be gate kept via the in game currency. forcing you into a suboptimal set up purely because you dont want to spend real money on the game.

3. The amount of false positives with fish being lost to line tension is ridiculous. Tension could be maintained perfectly and the fish will somehow fall off as its being pulled from the water into your hand. If you want to keep that mechanic in the game then at least give us the option of a net or something to help pull the fish in. Level 30 currently and no such option available.

4. The amount of times ive lost multiple fish because the game won't let me switch rods on a holder is becoming an issue to the point I have to change my review and not recommend this game unless you have prior experience in similar games. Its a level of cruelty that shouldnt be an issue, if the devs simply played their game. And certainly one would expect issues like this to be non existent after being out for 10 years. Truly a terrible experience. Please do something about it as it is limiting this game severely

If you don't care about optimisation and just want to throw a line in the water to get some fish then its a pretty good game. The more you try to optimise, the more the game breaks ://

Edit: complete cash grab of a game. Just don't play it in general honestly

I can't believe I ever bought this game thinking it would be a nice and cozy game...
13 minutes in and Im not impressed. The controls feel clunky, the progression is slow, and it didnt hook me at all.

Uses Denuvo

Edit; The Developer decided to respond on why they use Denuvo. Below are just a few reason to be wary of developers who use Denuvo.

Denuvo performs constant integrity checks, encryption/decryption, and verification of the game executable during runtime, which can consume CPU resources.

Independent testing showed frame-time spikes and longer load times when Denuvo was enabled.

Some versions of Denuvo require periodic, or constant, online authentication. This can lock out legitimate users when Denuvoâ€™s servers are down or when internet access is unreliable.

Because Denuvo performs repeated reads (and possibly writes), this can contribute to increased wear on SSDs.

Because Denuvo is proprietary, users donâ€™t really know exactly what checks are happening, how often, or how invasive they are.

If Fishing Planet removes Denuvo in the future, I'll gladly update my review, but as it stands, I can't recommend it.

22 hours in great game but it is a scam for your money ie: BATECOIN and a few other in game currency.

Besides catching bluegill in a pond, you wont progress any farther without spending money. When I say money I mean HUNDREDS of dollars, that deep sea thing you see in the beginning will cost you 200 or so to even try it. 

Seriously DO NOT WASTE YOUR TIME

When you buy an unlimited license, it is only unlimited for a limited time. This game isn't about fishing. This is a scummy money grabber. You have to close out of 3 or 4 popup screens that try to get you buy stuff before you can even play. It's ridiculous and annoying af. I'm going to go find a good fishing game.

It's an addicting game and really good but far too many micro transactions.

The game is heavily dependent on bait coins.  You aren't "required" to purchase anything but you will be stuck in Texas catching 0.3 pound bluegill if you don't.  Pond passes, advanced license's and in game credits won't carry you to any fun.  If you buy a $39 dollar pack, you'll be fishing in the Congo with the biggest fish and best rods immediately.    

The leaderboards are also quite laughable, there are no 1 million pound fish. 

Removal of baitcoin and actual substantial rewards for fish you catch would be better for the game but not so great for the devs pockets.  I'm not against a few packs, but baitcoin is clear pay to win.

Am I still playing?  Sure, but not if another game close to this with no baitcoin comes out....

The game a total money grab, good game shitty company. to do any thing you pretty much have to pay money or not get no where. beside it take 2hours to reel in a fish some time.i dont have time to waste 2hours on one fish it rediculous. i have a life too.its a game and suppose to be fun nothing fun about that.  you get the base game free which let you play but after that your digging deep in your wallet for nothing really. dont waste your time look else,or else you got nothing better to do with your money and time.
Hard to learn how to play. Why is a fishing game so complicated? Fishing in real life isn't as complicated ffs. Just a very annoying and frustrating experience. Make it easier to play please.

Listen, I downloaded Fishing Planet because I thought itâ€™d be a relaxing fishing game. You knowâ€”cast a line, vibe with some southern tunes, catch a pixelated fish or two, and feel like a serene outdoorsy legend.

WRONG.

This game decided it wanted to be a hyperrealistic fishing simulator. I spent 47 real-life minutes staring at digital water while my avatar slowly froze to death in photorealistic rain.

I finally hooked one, and the game made me reel for eight full minutes while adjusting my line tension like I was defusing a bomb. I think my thumb developed emotional trauma. By the time I caught it, I felt like Iâ€™d actually gone fishingâ€”minus the tan and plus a mild existential crisis.

And the realism! My bait ran out. My rod broke. I had to file taxes on my in-game fishing income. I didnâ€™t sign up for Fishing Bureaucracy Simulator 3000.

Sure, the graphics are stunning, the water physics are gorgeous, and the fish AI deserves an Oscarâ€”but please, I play games to escape reality, not to be humbled by a trout.

dont understand why this game has so many positive reviews, everywhere you look the game wants you to buy premium stuff.

The game is fun and the interaction is pretty close to IRL fishing. The biggest negative here is the company's standard response is it's ISP, your internet ect. when in fact it's their application and server load balancing. They refuse to acknowledge or fix the can't connect to server when it's 100% thier issue. has been for several months now. Play at your own risk :)

it is free to play, up to a certain point. which is okay, its free to catch bass in a small pond. thats enough tbh. if you want to have fun by fishing anywhere else, you must pay thousands of USD to unlock paid features like boats, ocean fishing, large rods, bait, premium passes to the paid areas on top of paying for access to those areas. if you want to play to win, heres the math, they keep increasing it with every update to make it impossible to play to win, you would have to grind the most profitable free fish for literally 9 months straight with no breaks to be able to level up and earn enough points to do it. i tested it personally after the developers banned me from their discord for asking why they keep decreasing the amount of exp a fish gains per catch. was good at first when you could earn your way up, now its another cash grab scam. dont recommend. try russian fishing sim instead
